Dear Ms. McBride:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer, at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff took a resident to their home on at least five occasions. Staff
and her husband were drunk and driving with the resident in the
car on 7/4/24.
Investigation On 7/16/24 Complainant reported that Staff 1 took Youth A to her
home on 7/4/24. Staff 1’s children, husband, and extended family
were present at the home. Staff 1’s husband was drinking alcohol
and later drove Staff 1, Youth A, and some children to a park to
watch fireworks. Staff 1’s husband was intoxicated and going over
the speed limit. Staff 1 was also believed to have been drinking
alcohol at the facility on an unknown date. Complainant was
contacted on 7/17/24 and did not have any additional information.
On 7/17/24 Foster Care Worker was contacted via email and
provided information about the investigation.
On 7/17/24 Chief Administrator was notified of the investigation
by email, as they were not present at the facility when an
unannounced visit occurred. Chief Administrator reported that
Staff 1 was placed on administrative leave, pending investigation.
Documents were requested from Chief Administrator via email on
7/22/24, 8/13/24, 8/14/24, and 8/26/24.
On 7/17/24 Youth A was interviewed in person at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported that Staff 1
took the youth to the staff’s home on 7/4/24. Staff 1 transported
Youth A to the home in her personal car. They were at Staff 1’s
house for about 45 minutes, then went to the store to pick up
some groceries for dinner. Youth A ate dinner with Staff 1 and her
family at Staff 1’s house. The family included Staff 1’s mother,
children, and husband. While eating dinner, Staff 1’s husband took
2

a bottle of brown liquor outside to drink. Staff 1 followed her
husband outside, where they stayed for approximately twenty
minutes.
Around 9:00PM everyone went to the home of Staff 1’s extended
family, to pick up fireworks. Youth A stayed in the car while Staff 1
went inside. Staff 1’s husband was driving “a little crazy”. Staff 1
told her husband to calm down and slow down. Youth A saw the
speedometer indicated he was going 50mph in a 25mph area.
Youth A clarified that Staff 1, the husband, one of their children,
and Youth A were in the car at the time. After picking up the
fireworks, they went to a park in the area and set off the fireworks.
Staff 1’s husband was the one that lit the fireworks, Youth A did
not light any. While at the park, Staff 1’s husband drank a beer.
The beer can was described as tall, blue and silver, and larger
than a normal can. As they were leaving the park, Staff 1’s
husband almost backed into a car. He then began driving back to
Staff 1’s house, speeding. Staff 1 told her husband to pull over,
stating, “you’re too drunk to drive”. Youth A was scared by this.
Staff 1 then got into the driver’s seat and proceeded home. Staff 1
dropped her husband off at their home, then headed back to the
facility. Staff 1 was on the phone with her mother while driving.
Staff 1 stopped at a gas station to buy a vape. When Staff 1 got
back in the car, her phone connected to the speakers and Youth A
could hear the conversation. Youth A heard Staff 1’s mother
comment about her husband almost hitting a car in the parking lot
at the park. Staff 1 said, “yeah, he was really drunk”. Staff 1 then
took Youth A back to the facility.
Youth A stated she had gone to Staff 1’s home five or six times
since moving to the program in May 2024. Youth A never stayed
the night at Staff 1’s home. Youth A recalled being at the house
for about seven hours one day in June 2024. Youth A stated that
Staff 1’s family was always present at the house. Staff 1 never
had her husband or children at the facility. However, Youth A
recalled hearing Staff 1 ask her husband to come spend the night
with her at the facility, but her husband said no.
Youth A stated she never saw Staff 1 drink alcohol at the facility.
However, she recalled getting in Staff 1’s car and realizing her
breath smelled like alcohol once. Youth A stated this was also in
June 2024. Youth A confirmed that Staff 1 had not been to the
facility since 7/4/24. Youth A stated she saw Staff 1 vape while at
work. Staff 1 never bought a vape for Youth A.
3

On 7/17/24 Staff 2 was interviewed in person at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she was not
aware Staff 1 took Youth A to her home. Staff 2 never witnessed
Staff 1 or any other staff take youth to their home. Staff 2 stated all
staff are aware it is not appropriate to transport youth in their
personal car or take youth to their home. Staff 2 also stated that
staff are not supposed to use any substances, such as a vape,
while at the facility or transporting youth. Staff 2 recalled that Staff
1 once had a vape in her pocket while at the house. All staff were
instructed to leave personal items in their vehicle. Staff 2 did not
have any other concerns about Staff 1.
On 7/17/24, 9/4/24, and 9/17/24 attempts were made to contact
Staff 1 by phone. On 9/18/24 Staff 1 was interviewed by phone.
Staff 1 reported that she did transport Youth A to her home, in her
car. Staff 1 stated her mother, fiancé and children were present.
Staff 1 reported they were only at her house briefly before going to
the store to purchase fireworks and food to grill at the park. Staff 1
stated Youth A did not have dinner at her house. Staff 1, her
family, and Youth A went to the park and grilled for dinner. Her
fiancé then lit off some fireworks. Staff 1 reported that she drove
the entire time, with her fiancé in the passenger seat, and her
child in the back seat with Youth A. Staff 1 denied having any
alcohol that day, or any other day when working. Staff 1 reported
her fiancé also did not have any alcohol and does not drink and
drive. Staff 1’s fiancé is a truck driver and any violation of that
nature would ruin his career.
Staff 1 stated the agency policy was not clear about transporting
youth in her personal car, with her children. Staff 1 said she had
never transported any agency youth with her children prior to that
day. Staff 1 verified that Youth A had been to her home a few
times but had never gone inside previously. Staff 1 said that she
had been out running errands with Youth A before, such as
picking the youth up from community service, and stopped at her
home to pick up something. Youth A waited in the car and did not
have contact with her family that time.
Staff 1 stated she had never been investigated before and having
MDHHS involved was very scary. Staff 1 stated that she was told
Youth A had since changed or recanted her allegation regarding
the alcohol and had also made other false claims about other
staff.
4

On 9/18/24 Chief Administrator reported that Staff 1 was
accurate in her statement that Youth A admitted to making up the
information about alcohol.
Documents reviewed
• The Human Resources file for Staff 1 indicated she was
hired on 2/2/23 and completed orientation and training on
all agency policies. Staff 1 did not have any disciplinary
action on file.
• The agency policy titled “Use of Personal Vehicle” revised
2/19/2020, states a personal vehicle may only be used for
company business and with supervisory approval, only if a
company vehicle is unavailable. The policy further states
staff are strictly prohibited from transporting unauthorized
persons in the presence of individuals receiving services or
while on company business.
• The agency policy titled “Facility Access” revised
2/17/2020, indicates staff cannot allow family/friends to visit
the facility, as it would violate the youth’s privacy.
Technical Assistance
The agency was advised to update their policy to clearly state that
staff are not to take youth to their personal home, or in their
personal vehicle with family, or on unapproved outings with
family/friends of staff.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as interviews determined
Staff 1 violated agency policy by taking Youth A to her home,
where her family was present. Staff 1 also transported Youth A in
her personal vehicle, with her family, to a family outing.
The allegation regarding Staff 1 or her fiancé drinking and driving
with Youth A present, could not be confirmed.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and a Corrective Action Plan is required.
